content: Modern supply chain management relies on network analysis to optimize the flow of goods from manufacturers to consumers.
Supply chain networks are modeled as complex adaptive systems where nodes represent facilities and edges represent transportation links or business relationships.
Hub-and-spoke configurations enable economies of scale but create potential single points of failure.
Direct shipping networks offer greater flexibility and resilience but result in higher per-unit transportation costs.
Disruptions at tier-two suppliers can propagate forward through the supply chain to affect multiple downstream manufacturers.
Network mapping and visualization tools are used to gain visibility into extended supply networks beyond direct suppliers.
Supply chain network optimization requires balancing cost minimization, service level maximization, and environmental objectives.
